name: ENGW 1111
title:
First Year Writing
ENGW 1111
content:
Ah, reflections. I could never stand writing them and I most of the time I didn't even want to read them. So I decided to do something a little different for this one.

This is a tree layout of the projects I did over the course of the semester including the topics and various research paths that stemmed from them. The projects are available on my portfolio on Digication.

Items with a are clickable and expand the tree to show the next level of items
Items with a are the end of a branch and don't expand

children.name: P1: The Writing We Do
children.title:
The Writing We Do
Project 1
children.content:
We read and write a surprising amount throughout our daily lives, often without even noticing. This project was an attempt to recognize and log instances of reading and writing as well as to reflect on any patterns or surprising trends that appeared.

What I found during this project, was a little surprising to me. I don't consider myself a writer, but the hours I spent writing far outnumbered the time I spent doing anything else. The reason for that however was because I was programming.

children.name: Programming
children.content: I spent the majority of my time programming and although it seems like a bit of a stretch to call it writing, the thought processes are very similar. Both programming and writing have some kind of end goal and require multiple stages of editing to reach a well-polished final product. Both of them can also involve research to begin and editing by peers to ensure that no errors exist. The only real difference between them is the language you write in.

children.name: Reading
children.content: The reading I logged over the tracking period was, for the most part, reading for pleasure. One in particular was a book called Cracking the Coding Interview which explains how someone could prepare for a coding interview and some sample problems that could appear.

children.name: P2: Community Profile
children.title:
Community Profile
Project 2
children.content: Different communities can be found everywhere and are greatly varied in every aspect. This project described a community with a specific interest and identified some defining characteristics of the group. In my case, it was the community of deception-based board game players. I collected information from interviews with players of these games and by drawing on my own knowledge and experience.

children.name: Computer Scientists
children.content: Initially, I thought about showcasing the computer science community. I was planning on defining some key characteristics of the different computer related fields that people go into.

children.name: Databases
children.content: People who work with data structures and databases of any kind. Whether it be lists, arrays, binary trees, dictionaries, or graphs, Database Engineers need to know them all and utilize them in the correct situations. As for the configuration of the database, they would need to know either SQL or a noSQL schema.

children.name: Programming
children.content: Programming is a core area of computer science of which there is a wide variety of things it can be extended to. If you're in CS, it's pretty much expected that you'll know two programming langauges at a minimum.

children.name: Low-level
children.title: Low-level Programming
children.content:
section    .text
    global _start   ;must be declared for linker (ld)
_start:                ;tells linker entry point
    mov    edx,len     ;message length
    mov    ecx,msg     ;message to write
    mov    ebx,1       ;file descriptor (stdout)
    mov    eax,4       ;system call number (sys_write)
    int    0x80        ;call kernel

    mov    eax,1       ;system call number (sys_exit)
    int    0x80        ;call kernel

section    .data
msg db 'Hello, world!', 0xa  ;string to be printed
len equ $ - msg     ;length of the string

Assembly code that will print out "Hello, world!"

Low-level programming deals with instructions that are sent directly to the computer.

children.name: High-level
children.title: High-level Programming
children.content:
print("Hello, world!")

Python code will print out "Hello, world!"

High-level programming deals with programming algorithms and handling data. Code written in a high-level langauge is much more human readable than that of a low-level language and is often where people start learning to program. A common field in high-level programming is web development because, for the most part, websites don't have to access the core parts of a computer in order to serve their purpose.

children.name: Board Game Players
children.content: The community of board game players is exceedingly large so I decided to break it up even further to target a more specific group of people without restricting it to a certain field.

children.name: Strategy
children.content: The first genre of games I thought of was of strategy games. Games like Risk or Chess. However, I felt that I may only find a very specific type of people who played these types of games. Those who are thinkers, planners, and tacticians. I didn't think I would see very much diversity in this genre as opposed to some others.

children.name: Classics
children.content: I considered interviewing players of what I called the classics genre of games. These would be games like Monopoly, Sorry, The Game of Life, Pictionary, etc. This was a viable choice but I didn't really feel much of an interest in doing it.

children.name: Deception
children.content: Deception-based games. Now this was a topic that I was very interested in, even more so because I had found a set of people on my floor who were also very into playing this type of game. It was a fairly clear choice to pick this genre because I love the concept of trying to convince people of something that is not always true.

children.name: Types of players
children.content: After interviewing some players, I compiled a list of the types of personalities that appear during the games.

children.name: Statistician
children.content: Decisions are based on probabilities

children.name: Logician
children.content: Decisions are made by logical elimination

children.name: Psychologist
children.content: Decisions are based on behaviors of others

children.name: Trickster
children.content: Makes claims that throw off the general consensus of the group

children.name: Random
children.content: Randomly says things to throw people off

children.name: Common Traits
children.content:
• Poker face - ability to control facial expressions to give suggestive hints to others
  • Adaptability - ability to recover from an upset by a trickster
  • Levels - how far the actions of others are predicted

children.name: P3: Globe-style Article
children.title:
Globe-style Article
Project 3
children.content: This essay was to be written in the style of a Globe magazine article to expose discussion on an argument. The topic I chose was on artificial intelligence and its applications in the real world. The article bounces around between multiple different topics like philosophy and computer science from many different sources and references.

children.name: Machine Learning
children.content: Neural networks, self-driving cars, machine vision

children.name: Neuroscience
children.content: The Tale of The Dueling Neurosurgeons by Sam Kean, We Become What We Behold, Neurotic Neurons

children.name: Artificial Intelligence
children.content: self-aware, Skynet, The Matrix

children.name: Philosophy
children.content: Trolley problem

children.name: Me
children.title:
Me
As a writer
children.content: Being the cynical logician that I am, editing essays is much easier than generating content for them. In this way, I usually ended up with very short, direct essays. However, I never fully enjoyed writing in an English class before college. When I had topics I actually cared to write about, I was able to elaborate more than I normally did.

children.name: Strengths/Weaknesses
children.content: When writing about topics I actually cared to write about, I was able to elaborate more than I normally did. I still kept to my habit of creating a multilevel, list outline before each essay I wrote (as you can no doubt see by this tree) and I feel now that I can better expand on each point I thought of. I think my strengths and weaknesses are mostly the same as before, but I feel like I know that I have the potential to write more completely when I'm vested in the topic.

children.name: Procrastination
children.content: Procrastinating on essays was something I always did before (and still do in fact), but for essays I have an interest in, I don't leave everything until the night before anymore because I know that there's so much I want to get on the paper. Having things to write about was a new feeling for me as I hadn't ever had the chance to write essays about topics I wanted

children.name: Digication
children.content:
Having a platform like Digication to post works on helped me in some ways to set a specific tone of voice for a defined audience (as well themes to mess around with), but the web developer in me made it near impossible not to criticize the way the website was built. I was already used to creating content suitable for the web so structuring my content wasn't too difficult, but it was occasionally distracting to see some style on the page that didn't fit with the rest of the site and to edit the code to hide its effects.

I spend a lot of time tweaking the way my own website looks so I know how much effort it takes to create something that people will enjoy looking at. However, with Digication they appear to provide support for changing styles on your portfolio, but it's not truly available. In web development, styles are added to pages via files written in CSS. Digication does allow you to add in your own CSS stylesheet, but it doesn't evaluate what you type in correctly. It does not recognize any of the symbols which make CSS truly effective and locks out some basic styles such as fonts.

children.name: Future Plans
children.content: I'm definitely looking forward to developing my knowledge about neural networks and possibly more about how machine learning interacts with audio. After all the research I did for the essays in this course, I am even more certain that I want to know more. An idea I found an interest in stemmed from the fact that I'm always looking for music that both sounds good and has sheet music available. Unfortunately, good sheet music is often difficult to find or costs money to get access to. If a natural language processor was retrained with musical instruments instead of voices and could identify the notes being played, it might be able to generate sheet music for each part on its own which be extremely useful.
